details.title: Goodness-of-fit tests based on Kullback-Leibler information

p: Birdal Şenoğlu is an Asst. Prof. at Osmangazi University, Turkey. He received his B. S. degree in Statistics from Middle East Technical University and his M. S. degree in Statistics from Iowa State University. He received his Ph. D. degree in Statistics from Middle East Technical University. His main areas of interest are experimental design, robust statistics and goodness-of-fit tests.

Barış Sürücü is a Res. Asst. at Middle East Technical University, Turkey. He received his B. S., M. S. and Ph. D. in Statistics from Middle East Technical University. He is interested in goodness-of-fit tests and outlier detection procedures.

details.abstract: We evaluate the power of the sample entropy goodness-of-fit tests for s-normal, exponential, and uniform distributions. We compare them with the mainstream statistical tests, the W test based on the best linear unbiased estimator (BLUE) of the location parameter, the Z test based on the sample spacings, and the R test based on the correlation coefficient between the order statistics of the sample & the corresponding population quantiles. We show that the latter are more powerful overall. The mainstream statistical tests, particularly the Z test, readily extend to censored samples and to multi-sample situations.

references.title: A test for normality based on Kullback-Leibler information

context.text: Tests based on sample entropy (Kullback-Leibler information) are often used; see, for example, ([1], [3], [5]–[7], [11], [12], [17], [19], [25], and [27]).

references.text: I. Arizono, H. Ohta, "A test for normality based on Kullback-Leibler information", American Statistician, vol. 34, pp. 20-23, 1989.

references.title: Emprical power study of a multisample test of exponentiality based on spacings

context.text: The \$Z\$ test is known to be overall the most powerful test of \$E(\theta,\sigma)\$; see, for example, [2] and [4].
They can also be used for testing outliers ([13], [15], [30] and [31]), and readily extend to censored samples and to multi-sample situations ([2], [4], [29], [32], [33]).

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, "Emprical power study of a multisample test of exponentiality based on spacings", Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation, vol. 18, pp. 265-271, 1983.

references.title: Entropy based tests of uniformity

context.text: Tests based on sample entropy (Kullback-Leibler information) are often used; see, for example, ([1], [3], [5]–[7], [11], [12], [17], [19], [25], and [27]).
The sample entropy statistic for testing the uniform U(0,1) is given in [3] which is exactly the same as \$H_{mn}\$ in (7) above.
As an omnibus test, small and large values of \$K_{mn}\$ lead to the rejection of \$U(\theta_{1},\theta_{2})\$; \$m\$ is chosen to maximize the power [3].
We simulated the power of \$K_{mn}\$ and \$R\$ tests for twelve alternatives, primarily the ones considered in [3].

references.text: E. Dudewicz, E. Van der Meulen, "Entropy based tests of uniformity", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 76, pp. 967-974, 1981.

context.text: Tests based on sample entropy (Kullback-Leibler information) are often used; see, for example, ([1], [3], [5]–[7], [11], [12], [17], [19], [25], and [27]).

Given the \$n\$ order statistics from (2) of a random sample of size \$n\$ from the exponentialthe sample entropy statistic is \$(\theta=0)\$where [5]\$m\$ is a positive integer smaller than \$n/2\$, \$x_{(j)}=x_{(1)}\$ if \$j<1\$, and \$x_{(j)}=x_{(n)}\$ if \$j>n\$.
The values of \$m\$ in \$K_{mn}\$ were chosen as recommended in [5].

links.abstract: This paper proposes a test-of-fit for exponentiality of the residual life (TF-ERL) based on the estimated dynamic Kullback-Leibler information. TF-ERL applies when the exponential parameter is or is not specified under the null hypothesis. Asymptotic properties of TF-ERL are discussed. In particular, the TF-ERL is shown to be a statistically consistent test of the null hypothesis for all alternatives. Small-sample null tail probabilities are derived; critical values are tabulated; and its use is...

references.text: N. Ebrahimi, M. Habibullah, E. S. Soofi, "Testing exponentiality based on Kullback-Leibler information", Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, vol. 54, pp. 739-748, 1992.

context.text: We simulate the power of the modified tests, and compare with the competing omnibus tests, namely: Shapiro-Wilk ([19], [20]) type \$W\$ test based on BLUE of scale, which is particularly powerful for testing \$s\$-normality; Tiku ([32], [33]) type \$Z\$ test based on sample spacings, which is particularly powerful for testing exponentiality; and Filliben [8], and Smith & Bain [24] type \$R\$ test based on sample correlation which is particularly powerful for testing uniformity.
The corresponding correlation statistic is ([8], [24])\$\mathhat{\rho}\$ is the correlation coefficient between \$x_{(i)}\$ and \$k_{i}\$, \$1\leq i\leq n\$.

references.title: A simple goodness-of-fit test for the power-law process, based on the Duane plot

links.abstract: The PLP (power-law process) or the Duane model is a simple model that can be used for both reliability growth and reliability deterioration. GOF (goodness-of-fit) tests for the PLP have attracted much attention. However, the practical use of the PLP model is its graphical analysis or the Duane plot, which is a log-log plot of the cumulative number of failures versus time. This has been commonly used for model validation and parameter estimation. When a plot is made, and the coefficient of determ...

references.text: O. Gaudoin, B. Yang, M. Xie, "A simple goodness-of-fit test for the power-law process based on the Duane plot", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 52, no. 1, pp. 69-74, 2003.

links.abstract: Our new method uses order statistics to judge the fit of a distribution to data. A test-statistic based on quantiles of order-statistics compares favorably with the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (K-S) and Anderson-Darling (A-D) test statistics. The performance of this new goodness-of-fit test statistic is examined with simulation experiments. For certain hypothesis tests, the test statistic is more powerful than the K-S and A-D test statistics. The new test statistic is calculated using a computer algebra ...

references.text: A. G. Glen, L. M. Leemis, D. R. Barr, "Order statistics in goodness-of-fit testing", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 50, no. 2, pp. 209-213, 2001.

links.abstract: This study investigates the properties of the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (K-S), Cramer-von Mises (C-M) and Anderson-Darling (A-D) statistics for goodness-of-fit tests for type-I extreme-value and for 2-parameter Weibull distributions, when the population parameters are estimated from a complete sample by graphical plotting techniques (GPT). Three GPT-median ranks, mean ranks, symmetrical sample cumulative distribution (symmetrical ranks)-are combined with the least-squares method (LSM) on extreme-value ...

references.text: T. Shimokawa, M. Liao, "Goodness-of-fit tests for type-I extreme-value and 2-parameter Weibull distributions", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 48, no. 1, pp. 79-86, 1999.

links.abstract: We present a general methodology for developing asymptotically distribution-free goodness-of-fit tests based on the Kullback-Leibler discrimination information. The tests are shown to be omnibus within an extremely large class of nonparametric global alternatives and to have good local power. The proposed test procedure is a nonparametric extension of the classical Neyman-Pearson log-likelihood ratio test and is based on mth-order spacings between order statistics cross-validated by the observed...

references.text: K. S. Song, "Goodness-of-fit tests based on Kullback-Liebler discrimination information", IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, vol. 48, pp. 1103-1117, 2002.

references.title: A new statistic for testing for normality

context.text: A directional test is one which is used for testing an assumed distribution against certain types of alternatives, e.g., testing exponential which has skewness \$\sqrt{\beta_{1}}=2\$ against alternatives which have \$\sqrt{\beta_{1}}<2\$ [28].
The \$W\$ test is known to be the most powerful test of \$s\$-normality overall; see, for example, [28].
It may be noted that statistics based on sample spacings, and variants of it, can be used for testing any distribution ([28], [29], and [35]).

references.text: M. L. Tiku, "A new statistic for testing for normality", Communications in Statistics, vol. 3, pp. 223-232.

references.title: Goodness-of-fit statistics based on the spacings of complete or censored samples

context.text: We simulate the power of the modified tests, and compare with the competing omnibus tests, namely: Shapiro-Wilk ([19], [20]) type \$W\$ test based on BLUE of scale, which is particularly powerful for testing \$s\$-normality; Tiku ([32], [33]) type \$Z\$ test based on sample spacings, which is particularly powerful for testing exponentiality; and Filliben [8], and Smith & Bain [24] type \$R\$ test based on sample correlation which is particularly powerful for testing uniformity.
For the \$Z\$ statistic (testing exponentiality) the exact null distribution is known [32], which converges to \$s\$-normal very quickly.
The exponential spacings are defined asFor testing the exponential \$E(\theta,\sigma)\$, Tiku [32] proposed the statisticSmall and large values of \$Z\$ lead to the rejection of exponentiality.
The null distribution of \$(1/2)Z\$ is the same as the distribution of the mean of \$n-2\$ i.i.d uniform (0,1) variates [32], which converges to \$s\$-normal very quickly.
The \$R\$ test is particularly powerful for testing \$U(\theta_{1},\theta_{2})\$ against symmetric alternatives ([32], [33]).
They can also be used for testing outliers ([13], [15], [30] and [31]), and readily extend to censored samples and to multi-sample situations ([2], [4], [29], [32], [33]).

references.text: M. L. Tiku, "Goodness-of-fit statistics based on the spacings of complete or censored samples", Australian Journal of Statistics, vol. 22, pp. 260-275, 1980.

references.title: A goodness-of-fit statistic based on the sample spacings for testing a symmetric distribution against symmetric alternatives

context.text: We simulate the power of the modified tests, and compare with the competing omnibus tests, namely: Shapiro-Wilk ([19], [20]) type \$W\$ test based on BLUE of scale, which is particularly powerful for testing \$s\$-normality; Tiku ([32], [33]) type \$Z\$ test based on sample spacings, which is particularly powerful for testing exponentiality; and Filliben [8], and Smith & Bain [24] type \$R\$ test based on sample correlation which is particularly powerful for testing uniformity.
The \$R\$ test is particularly powerful for testing \$U(\theta_{1},\theta_{2})\$ against symmetric alternatives ([32], [33]).
They can also be used for testing outliers ([13], [15], [30] and [31]), and readily extend to censored samples and to multi-sample situations ([2], [4], [29], [32], [33]).

references.text: M. L. Tiku, "A goodness-of-fit statistic based on the sample spacings for testing a symmetric distribution against symmetric alternatives", Australian Journal of Statistics, vol. 23, pp. 149-158, 1981.

references.title: Testing the two parameter Weibull distribution

context.text: It may be noted that statistics based on sample spacings, and variants of it, can be used for testing any distribution ([28], [29], and [35]).
For example, Tiku and Singh [35] use such statistics for testing Weibull and extreme-value distributions considered in [22].
Extensions of this work to multivariate distributions is in progress [26]; see also [35].

references.text: M. L. Tiku, M. Singh, "Testing the two parameter Weibull distribution", Communications in Statistics̵Theory and Methods, vol. A10, pp. 907-918, 1981.

references.title: A test for normality based on sample entropy

context.text: The purpose of this paper is to modify the earlier tests based on sample entropy so that they are location and scale invariant, and can be used as omnibus tests of exponentiality and uniformity, as is the sample entropy test of \$s\$-normality given in [36].

Using the Kullback-Leibler measure of information, the proposed statistic is [36]where \$s^{2}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-\bar{x})^{2}/n\$ is the sample variance, and \$m\$ is a positive integer less than \$n/2\$; \$x_{(i)}=x_{(1)}\$ if \$i<1\$, and \$x_{(i)}=x_{(n)}\$ if \$i>n\$.
The null distribution of \$K_{mn}\$ is not known, but its Monte Carlo percentage points are given in [36].
In fact, Vasicek [36] gives the values of \$m\$ so obtained for \$n=10\$, 20, and 50.

references.text: O. Vasicek, "A test for normality based on sample entropy", Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, vol. 38, pp. 54-59, 1976.

references.title: A central limit theorem for testing exponentiality

context.text: Moreover, the null distributions of the entropy statistics converge to their asymptotic forms (\$s\$-normal) far too slowly [37].
The convergence to \$s\$-normality is, however, very slow [37].

references.text: L. C. Zhao, H. Zhang, "A central limit theorem for testing exponentiality", Communications in Statistics̵Theory and Methods, vol. 30, no. 6, pp. 1163-1170, 2001.
